title: Urban Waste Collection & Recycling Drop-Off Coordination
content: A municipal waste management team operates trucks (capacity: `<capacity>`) from a depot (`<loc_depot>`) to collect mixed waste (trash `<demand_linehaul>`) and recyclables (`<demand_backhaul>`) from `<num_customer>` bins (`<loc_customer>`). Each bin has a strict collection time window (`<time_windows>`) to avoid overflow. Trucks may alternate between trash pickup and recyclable drop-off at processing centers (modelled as backhauls) without fixed order but must ensure capacity is never exceeded. Vehicles end routes at their final stop (e.g., a recycling plant), eliminating return trips. The goal is to minimize total distance while meeting all time constraints.

title: E-Commerce Same-Day Delivery with Returns Handling
content: A logistics provider offers same-day delivery and returns pickup for online orders. Vans (capacity: `<capacity>`) depart from a hub (`<loc_depot>`) to deliver packages (`<demand_linehaul>`) to customers (`<loc_customer>`) within narrow delivery windows (`<time_windows>`). Simultaneously, drivers collect returns (`<demand_backhaul>`) from other customers en route. Vehicles may serve deliveries and pickups in any order but must avoid capacity violations (e.g., returns reducing available space for deliveries). Routes terminate at the last stop, reducing idle time. Optimize for minimal travel distance and on-time performance.

title: Farm-to-Table Produce Distribution with Surplus Collection
content: A farm cooperative uses refrigerated trucks (capacity: `<capacity>`) to deliver fresh produce (`<demand_linehaul>`) to restaurants (`<loc_customer>`) during morning hours (`<time_windows>`). After deliveries, trucks collect unsold surplus (`<demand_backhaul>`) from earlier stops to redistribute to food banks. Mixed sequences are allowed (e.g., deliver to Restaurant A → pick up surplus from B → deliver to C), but capacity must be managed dynamically. Trucks finish routes at the final food bank. The objective is to balance freshness (meeting tight delivery windows) and redistribution efficiency.

title: Medical Lab Specimen Transport with Sample Returns
content: A diagnostic lab dispatches couriers (capacity: `<capacity>`) from a central facility (`<loc_depot>`) to collect time-sensitive specimens (`<demand_backhaul>`) from clinics (`<loc_customer>`) within strict windows (`<time_windows>`). Couriers also deliver pre-packaged test kits (`<demand_linehaul>`) to the same clinics. Since specimens degrade, pickups must occur precisely within their windows, while deliveries can be interleaved flexibly. Couriers end routes at the lab’s testing center. Optimize for minimal travel time while prioritizing specimen viability.

title: Construction Material Delivery with Debris Removal
content: A construction supplier sends trucks (capacity: `<capacity>`) from a warehouse (`<loc_depot>`) to deliver materials (`<demand_linehaul>`) to `<num_customer>` sites (`<loc_customer>`) during work hours (`<time_windows>`). Trucks also collect debris (`<demand_backhaul>`) from sites for recycling. Deliveries and pickups can occur in any order (e.g., deliver to Site 1 → collect from Site 2 → deliver to Site 3), but debris volume must not block material loading. Routes end at the recycling yard. Minimize total distance while adhering to site access windows.

title: Retail Store Inventory Replenishment & Expired Product Collection
content: A retail chain operates a central warehouse (<loc_depot>) supplying fresh goods to <num_customer> stores (<loc_customer>), each with a unique demand (<demand>). Trucks (<capacity>) simultaneously deliver new stock and collect expired products (<demand_backhaul>) from stores, which must be processed within strict shelf-life time windows (<time_windows>). Drivers finish routes at their last store, eliminating return trips. The goal is to minimize travel costs while ensuring no truck exceeds capacity and all deliveries/pickups occur within freshness deadlines.

title: Mobile Vaccination Clinic Routing
content: A healthcare provider dispatches mobile clinics (<capacity> doses per vehicle) from a central hub (<loc_depot>) to administer vaccines at <num_customer> pop-up sites (<loc_customer>). Each site has a time-sensitive demand (<demand> + <time_windows>) and may return unused doses (<demand_backhaul>) for redistribution. Vehicles can serve sites in any order but must avoid dose spoilage by adhering to strict temperature-control time windows. Clinics remain at their final site for follow-ups, eliminating depot returns.

title: Industrial Parts Just-in-Time Delivery with Core Returns
content: An automotive supplier delivers custom parts (<demand>) to <num_customer> factories (<loc_customer>) from a distribution center (<loc_depot>) using trucks (<capacity>). Factories return defective cores (<demand_backhaul>) for refurbishment during the same visit. Deliveries must align with assembly line schedules (<time_windows>), and trucks may end routes at factories for maintenance. The challenge is balancing delivery/return loads dynamically while meeting tight production windows.

title: Event Catering Logistics with Leftover Recovery
content: A catering company services <num_customer> corporate events (<loc_customer>) from a kitchen hub (<loc_depot>) with refrigerated vans (<capacity>). Each event has a meal delivery window (<time_windows>) and may return uneaten food (<demand_backhaul>) for composting. Vans optimize routes to handle both deliveries and pickups in any sequence, finishing at the last event venue. The solution must prevent food waste by honoring time-sensitive pickup/drop-off constraints.

title: Library Bookmobile Routing with Returns
content: A county library operates bookmobiles (<capacity>) from a main branch (<loc_depot>) to <num_customer> neighborhood stops (<loc_customer>). Bookmobiles park overnight at their final stop to reduce empty mileage. The objective is maximizing access while minimizing operational costs.

title: Mobile COVID-19 Testing Unit Routing
content:
*Description:*  
A fleet of mobile testing vans (capacity: `<capacity>` test kits) departs from a central lab (`<loc_depot>`) to administer tests at `<num_customer>` pop-up sites (`<loc_customer>`). Each site has a time window (`<time_windows>`) for operation (e.g., 9 AM–12 PM at schools, 2 PM–5 PM at senior centers) and requires `<demand_linehaul>` test kits. Vans simultaneously collect completed test samples (`<demand_backhaul>`) for return to the lab. Routes must ensure:  
- No van exceeds capacity when combining deliveries/pickups.  
- Time windows are strictly adhered to (early arrivals wait).  
- Vans end routes at their final site (no return to depot).

title: Luxury Hotel Laundry Service with Express Turnaround
content:

Vans may serve hotels in any order (mixed linehaul/backhaul) but must avoid exceeding capacity when combining fresh (`<demand_linehaul>`) and soiled loads. Drivers finish shifts at their last hotel.

title: Art Gallery Installation & Deinstallation Tour
content:

title: Mobile Blood Donation Unit Routing with Donor Appointments
content:

✓ Dynamically balance pickups (donations) and drop-offs (supply replenishment)  
✓ Allow units to end routes at final collection sites (O) without returning  
✓ Avoid overloading units with collected blood while carrying fresh supplies
